direction.raw_text: Fills the screen. Falling from the top of frame to the bottom. Pluming off into dust. White, white, white. We move toward it even as it recedes, always out of reach. Finally we pop out wide and high to reveal... The white is chalk. An old BLACK GROUNDSKEEPER lays down the right field line on a baseball diamond. 1 INT. BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - MONTAGUE ST, BROOKLYN - DAY 1 Blinds closed. Dust motes in the air. A large GOLDFISH TANK bubbles. BRANCH RICKEY at his desk. Two photos on the wall: Abe Lincoln & Leo Durocher. CHALKBOARDS covered with 100's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: every player in the Dodger organization.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and HAROLD PARROTT sit across from Rickey who stares at them. Sukeforth stares back. Parrott nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, I have a plan... As of now, only the Board of Directors and my family know. Sukeforth and Parrott exchange a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A plan's always good, Mr. Rickey. And you always got one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife says I'm too old, That my health isn't up to it. My son says that every one in baseball will be against me. But I'm going to do it. Parrott looks to Sukeforth who keeps his eyes on Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do what, Mr. Rickey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to bring a Negro ballplayer to the Brooklyn Dodgers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all due respect, sir, have you lost your mind? Imagine the abuse you'll take from the newspapers alone. Never mind how it'll play on Flatbush. Please, Mr. Rickey. Rickey looks dismissively at Parrott, over to Sukeforth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no law against it, Clyde.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a code. Break a law and get away with it, some people think you're smart. Break an unwritten law though, you'll be an outcast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So be it. New York is full of Negro baseball fans; every dollar is green. I don't know who he is, or where he is, but he's coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RICKWOOD FIELD - BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA - NIGHT 2 The big Birmingham Black Barons CATCHER behind the plate as Kansas City Monarchs JOHN SCOTT stands at bat. The catcher's attention on the RUNNER DANCING off first. Stomping a foot, feinting, hard to see clearly in the glare of the lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd you learn to move like that, runner?! At dime a dance night?! Stay quiet!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Birmingham, Alabama. April 8, 1945. On the first pitch the runner takes off. The catcher fires to second. See it from his POV as the runner slides in aSAFE!a A foot on the bag, the runner dusts off, heckles the catcher:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that the best you got?! Huh?! I'm going to steal nine, ten bases today! You better start counting! The catcher frowns. Standing, we see he is a big, big man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's your shortstop from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got a mouth on him. Shaking his head, the catcher gets back in his crouch, signals the PITCHER. On the wind-up, the Runner is off again. The catcher fires to THIRD: aSafe!a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got a rag arm, catcher!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steal home! You'll find out what kind of arm I got!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLUE REV 7-9-12 3.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I'm coming! The Catcher looks over at Scott who chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: California, huh? (SCOTT NODS) Well California here he goes, if he comes down here. The Catcher gets back down in his squat. Signals the pitcher: fastball. Scott digs in, ready. The runner dancing off third. Here comes the wind-up... The Runner takes off even as the pitcher fires it in. The Birmingham Catcher receives it. As the Runner slides -- The Catcher intentionally drives his glove, the ball and both hands into the runner's face -- WHALLOP! Sound drops as we're knocked flat senseless along with the runner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: now as he tries to push himself up from the dirt. A close look at JACK ROOSEVELT ROBINSON. A born battler, he shakes out the cobwebs, finally lurches to his feet, looks to the UMPIRE. He never heard the call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was I? The umpire passes one hand over the other: Safe. Jack looks over at the catcher, gives him a pointed look as he goes -- The catcher shoves him in the back. Jack turns, shoves back. As the two men wrestles each other to the ground -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - MONTAGUE ST, BROOKLYN - DAY 3 Rickey and Sukeforth going through stacks of FILES on the desk. A black ballplayer's picture is clipped to each. As Rickey reviews one, Sukeforth tries to hand him another. SUKEFORTH Josh Gibson. Oh boy can he hit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No? Rickey won't take the file; the answer is no. DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 4.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Roy Campanella. Sukeforth holds it out; Rickey won't take it. RICKEY A heck of a player. But too sweet, they'll eat him alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holds up file) Satchel Paige then. Parrott enters carrying an armful of files. RICKEY Too old. We need a man with a future not a past. (holds up his own FILE) Here. Jack Roosevelt Robinson. As Parrott sets them on the desk, they start to slide off, spilling to the floor. Helpless to stem the tide, Parrott looks down, surrounded by black faces...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flips through file) A four sport college man, out of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . That means he's played with white boys. (SCANS FILE) Twenty-six years old, now with the Kansas City Monarchs. Batting over
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: even as we speak. 350! And he was a commissioned army officer!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was court-martialed. A trouble maker. He argues with umpires. A quick temper is his reputation. Rickey is obviously keen on him. PARROT What was he court-martialed for? RICKEY For refusing to sit in the back of a military bus. (checks the file) Ft. Hood, Texas. The driver asked him to move back. The MPs had to take him off. DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 5.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you see? RICKEY I see he resents segregation. If he were white, we'd call it spirit! PARROT If he were white, sir, we wouldn't be looking for him. Rickey ends the debate... RICKEY Robinson's a Methodist. I'm a Methodist. God's a Methodist. We can't go wrong. Find him. Bring him here. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FILLING STATION - INTERSTATE 24 - DAY 4 A BLOODHOUND watches as a BUS pulls into a SERVICE STATION, the tires RING the bell hose. A million miles easy on this road rumbler. The BANNER reads: KC Monarchs. Insert: Interstate 24, Missouri - August 24, 1945. The DRIVER steps off. The fellas follow, getting off to stretch their legs. Hot and tired. A WHITE ATTENDANT saunters out. The driver steps over to meet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fill her up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. The attendant starts unscrewing caps on two 50-GALLON TANKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you all headed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chicago. As the attendant shoves down a pump, starts filling, Jack steps off. He spots and heads for a restroom. White Men Only lettered on the door. The attendant roused as he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! Where you going, boy!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Everyone looking over as Jack stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to the toilet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit, boy, c'mon. You know you can't go in there. Jack does a slow burn, then suddenly strides toward the attendant. The air rife with tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take that hose out of the tank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it out. We'll get our ninety- nine gallons of gas someplace else. The attendant blinks. He takes a look from Jack to up and down the deserted highway. No business in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, use it. But don't stay in there too long. Jack heads back. The Driver, the players, a bit stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITE MEN ONLY REST ROOM - FILLING STATION - DAY 5 Jack splashes water on his face, rips a paper towels from the dispenser, pats his face dry. He balls the wad up, squeezes it in his fist before firing it into the trash. He considers his reflection in the mirror. As he regards himself, we hear the SERVICE BELL ring outside. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FILLING STATION - HIGHWAY 24 - DAY 6 A car has pulled up. The driver talks to several players. They look over as Jack exits. The driver is Clyde Sukeforth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you Jackie Robinson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - MONTAGUE ST, BROOKLYN - DAY 8 Blinds closed. Jack sits across the desk from Rickey. Sukeforth sits a little further back. Rickey is staring at Jack. Bushy eyebrows flared, light gleams off his glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : August 28, 1945. Brooklyn. Jack doesn't know what to do, looks to Sukeforth. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man needs a family relying on him. It insures he'll behave responsibly. Do you have a girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think so? Jack looks to Sukeforth who smiles placidly. Back to Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't make much money. Between the army and now baseball I've been away a lot. And Rae, Rachel, she wants to finish school. Considering all that, I say I think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love her? Rachel? (JACK CONFUSED) Don't you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir, very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marry her. What? Rickey stands, walks to a window. Jack looks at Sukeforth who raises a hand as if to say: Give it a chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baseball's a hard life; a man needs a good woman by his side. You don't want the only person waiting for you at home to be a catcher. Sukeforth chuckles at that. Rickey fingers open a slat on the blind and peers out. Jack looks hard at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coach Sukeforth here said you were starting a new Negro League. That doesn't make sense to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RICKEY It doesn't, huh? Are you calling us liars, Jack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this about, Mr. Rickey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is about baseball. Rickey opens the shade. Sunlight floods in. Rickey follows it to the chalkboard, to the list of players under Montreal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you starting in the spring with our affiliate in Montreal. If you make it there, we'll try you down here with the Dodgers. The white Brooklyn Dodgers. Jack looks to Sukeforth who nods: Yes, you heard right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll pay you $600 a month and a $3,500 bonus when you sign the contract. Is that agreeable? Believe it or not that's a lot of money to Jack on this day in time. This is all becoming a bit overwhelming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. That's fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is one condition. I have a pile of scouting reports. I know you can hit behind the runner, that you can read a pitch. The question is can you control your temper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My temper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes your temper! Are you deaf?! Rickey furious, the avuncular old man gone. Jack sits there, fists now balled. Rickey to Sukeforth like he's not there: RICKEY (CONT'D) He looks proud. Willful. SUKEFORTH He'll need to be. Rickey looks back to Jack who is as angry as he is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to win! I want ballplayers who can win! Are you one of them?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A black man in white baseball. Imagine the reaction. The vitriol. Rickey strides forward, gets in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Dodgers check into a hotel. A decent good hotel. You're worn out from the road and some clerk won't give you the pen to sign in. (SOUTHERN DRAWL) We got no room, boy, not even down in the coal bin where you belong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jack looks like he wants to tear Rickey apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The team stops at a restaurant. The waiter won't take your order. (adopts a new voice) Didn't you see the sign on the door? No animals allowed. (LOOMING) What are you going to do then? Fight him? Ruin all my plans? Answer me, you black sonofabitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want a ballplayer who doesn't have the guts to fight back? Is that what you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want one who has the guts not to fight back! There are people who will not like this. They will do anything to get you to react. If you echo a curse with a curse, they will only hear yours. Follow a blow with a blow and they will say a Negro lost his temper; that the Negro does not belong. Your enemy will be out in force, but you can not meet him on his own low ground. We win with hitting, running and fielding, nothing else. We win if the world is convinced of two things: that you are a fine gentlemen and a great ballplayer. Like our Savior, you must have the guts to turn the other cheek. Jack considers Rickey. Rickey looks worn out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you do it? Jack poised at what will be his Rubicon. He crosses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rickey, you give me a uniform, you give me a number on my back, and I'll give you the guts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - ISUM HOUSE - LOS ANGELES - DAY 9 A phone RINGS on a table. RACHEL ISUM steps in, 23, possessed of style that you can only be graced with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOBBY PAYPHONE - 215 MONTAGUE STREET - BROOKLYN - DAY 10 Jack in a PHONE BOOTH, the lobby busy beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rae, I'm in Brooklyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brooklyn? For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to say on the phone. In fact, I'm not supposed to tell anyone. She can hear the tingle in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack? JACK I'm here, Rae RACHEL What's going on? You're supposed to be playing in Chicago? JACK We've been tested you and me. Our loyalty, our faith. We've done everything the right way. Me trying to make money. You finishing school. Separated by the war, now by baseball. We don't owe the world a thing. Only each other. She's actually getting a little scared now. RACHEL Jack, what are you talking about? What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Brooklyn Dodgers just signed me to play ball up in Montreal. It might lead to bigger things. To something wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it mean? For you and me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rae. Will you marry me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely. When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, I don't think we can get married in a phone booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - THE CLARK HOTEL - LOS ANGELES - NIGHT 11 A Jack rounds a corner in a TUXEDO, the bow tie undone. Rachel follows in her WEDDING GOWN. They look beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did my mom look happy? JACK Yes. They reach the door. Jack gets out a key to unlock it. Rachel looks nervous, steps back across the hall. RACHEL Did my gram look happy? Swinging the door open, he looks at her. The air charged. JACK Everyone looked happy. I've never seen so many people looking happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did Jack Robinson look happy? (SOFT) What if I can't make you happy? He steps over, aware of her shyness. JACK Too late. You already do. It's you and me, Rae.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until the wheels fall off. (UNCERTAIN) The world is waiting for us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can wait one more night (KISSES HER) Are you coming, Mrs. Robinson? RACHEL (kisses him back) I'd follow you anywhere, Mr. Robinson. He picks her up, carries her over the threshold. As the door clicks shut behind them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 12 The shades closed; we're scheming again. WENDELL SMITH sits across from Rickey who stares back intently. Bespectacled,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smith covers baseball for the Pittsburgh Courier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's the best shortstop you ever saw?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rabbit Tavener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rabbit Tavener? And you call yourself a sports writer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, a sentimental one. I'm from Detroit. He was the Tiger shortstop when I was a boy. How about you? Who's your best?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop Lloyd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not Honus Wagner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wagner is number two. And Rabbit Tavener would not break my top 25. Where do you suppose Jackie Robinson will end up on that list?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't break it. He doesn't have a shortstop's arm. Robinson belongs on second base.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright then, where would he rate at second?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he was playing now he'd be the best second baseman in the majors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: High praise. He'll have to be the best in the minor leagues first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying, Mr. Rickey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm saying it's going to be a very interesting spring training. A lot of players are coming back from the war and with gas rationing over, we can train down in Florida again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daytona Beach? (RICKEY NODS) You're aware in the past six months a black boy was lynched in Madison, Florida and a black man down in Live Oaks?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those towns may as well be a million miles from Daytona.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Live Oaks is 150 actually.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spoke to the Daytona mayor. He assures me there'll be no trouble. But Rickey doesn't sound so sure. They consider each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Smith, are you a Communist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a Democrat. Why do you ask?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a business proposition. What's your salary at the Courier?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifty dollars a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will pay you an additional fifty dollars a week plus expenses if you will attend spring training with Jackie Robinson. You will watch over him, help him to avoid the harm that could come if he were to do or say anything out of turn. You will act as his chauffeur, you will secure accommodations for him wherever the team may be, help him find restaurants, etc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in it for me? Besides the fifty dollars and a whole lot of aggravation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unprecedented access for any reportage you feel appropriate. What do you say, Mr. Smith?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I say yes, sir. If a Negro is good enough to stop a Nazi bullet in France; he's good enough to stop a line drive at Yankee Stadium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ebbets Field actually, but yes, I agree. The world is ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BALLROOM - THE WALDORF ASTORIA HOTEL - NIGHT 14 Over 500 guests: journalists, players and politicians all listen politely as a SPEECH drones to an end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : New York City. 23rd Annual Baseball Writer's Association Dinner February 3, 1946.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As our former President Herbert Hoover remarked in his tribute to our national pastime: a The rigid voluntary rules of right and wrong, as applied in baseball, are second only to religion in strengthening the morals of the American people.' Polite applause as the speaker steps off. The clapping more enthusiastic as the lights dim on all but an impromptu set: plantation house columns. Hoots as a BUTLER appears wearing satin knee breeches and a MONTREAL ROYALS jersey. He holds a ring like a lawn jockey, a WHITE MAN in BLACK FACE. The laughs get louder as he peers out with exaggerated wide eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lordy, lordy, it's looking like da massa will be late dis ebning. As the LAUGHS from the audience subside, a sportswriter dressed as a COLONEL enters from stage right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robbie! Robbie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yassuh, Massa Kunl. Here Ah is. Huge LAUGHS as he struts and dances his way over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie, you woolly headed rascal. How long yo' been in the family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ebber since Massa Rickey done bots me from da Kansas City Monarchs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (aside to audience) Rickey that no good carpetbagger! What could he be thinking! Huge LAUGHS from that one. Two people enjoying it we'll recognize later as HERB PENNOCK and BOB COOKE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah came near bein' killed last night, Kunl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's that, Jackie boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah was comin' up a dark street and three men was behind me. And they tried to do me with a baseball bat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, suh. Ah recognized one of dem. Ah'm gonna hab him arrested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I thought you said it was dark?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was. But I know he played for the Philadelphia Baseball Club. On account of he struck at me three times and never hit me once. That brings the house down. Check out their laughing faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOCKHEED TERMINAL - BURBANK - DAY 15 A gleaming American Airlines DC-3 angled up on the tarmac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: climb the portable stairs and disappear inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : February 28, 1946. Burbank, California
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TERMINAL - BURBANK - DAY 16 Jack and Rachel are being seen off by FRIENDS from the wedding and his mother MALLIE. Jack is in a natty suit with Rachel in a beautiful coat. MALLIE You knock the cover off that ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will, Mama. Mallie hugs Jack and then kisses Rachel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look after each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will. She reaches in her bag, brings out a cardboard SHOEBOX; it's ever so slightly greasy at the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take this. It's chicken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have food on the plane, Mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never know what might happen. I don't want you getting there starving and too weak to hit. Rachel gives Jack a subtle but emphatic look: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOCKHEED TARMAC - BURBANK - DAY 17 Jack escorts Rachel to the plane, the shoebox in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't tell her no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know she means well; I just don't want to be seen eating chicken out of a box like some country bumpkin. Jack runs his hand over her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one's going to mistake you for a bumpkin in this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, they'll know I belong on that plane or wherever I happen to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DC-3 - DAY (STOCK FOOTAGE) 18 Descending toward a runway. Landing gear coming down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TERMINAL - NEW ORLEANS LAKEFRONT AIRPORT - DAY 19 A WOMAN exits the lady's room, passing a SIGN: White Only.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to show Rachel looking at it like she's been slapped. Jack joins Rae from the TICKET COUNTER, with the chicken box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : New Orleans Lakefront Airport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The flight to Pensacola leaves in an hour... You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've just never seen one before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (follows her look) We're not in Pasadena anymore. A sudden momentum carries her forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey... Rae -- He takes a step after her, stops as she disappears inside. Jack unsure what to do. He looks around. Looks back. He doesn't need this right now. 20 OMITTED 20 21 OMITTED 21 PINK REV 4-19-12 19.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPORT COFFEE SHOP - DAY 22 A black BUSBOY reacts as a bickering Jack and Rachel enter. JACK I promised Mr. Rickey we'd stay out of trouble. RACHEL Did you promise him we wouldn't go to the bathroom? You've done it. JACK Before I promised. RACHEL It was just a toilet. You'd think the commodes were made of gold. The busboy watches as Jack and Rachel slide into a booth. As Jack reaches for a MENU, here comes the COOK. COOK You folks can't sit here. JACK Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's white only. Jack looking to Rachel; it's equanimity time. Not easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll sell you some sandwiches. But you gotta take a em to go. Jack looks to the busboy, back to the cook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You hang onto those. Mastering himself, Jack slides out. Drilling the cook with a look, he offers his hand to Rachel as she slides out as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TERMINAL - NEW ORLEANS LAKEFRONT AIRPORT - DAY 24 Seen from on high. Jack and Rachel, sitting on a bench, two little figures as passengers move along the concourse. They sit a bit apart from each other, the world a wedge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RUNWAY - PENSACOLA AIRPORT - NIGHT 25 SMOKE PINWHEELS as the wheels of a BOEING 247 touch down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Pensacola, Florida. Later that day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOEING 247 - TARMAC - NIGHT 26 Jack and Rachel worn out among eight other passengers. As the door is opened, FOUR of the eight get up and disembark. After a beat, FOUR NEW PASSENGERS board and take their seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a hop to Daytona now. As Rachel nods, an AIRLINE EMPLOYEE boards, MISS BISHOP. She makes her way over. She spots who she's looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack Robinson? Come with me. She starts away without explaining, looks back at them a bit impatiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on now. Both of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TICKET COUNTER - PENSACOLA AIRPORT - NIGHT 27 The shoe box sitting on the counter, Jack in mid discussion with Miss Bishop. Rachel just behind Jack. MISS BISHOP We have to lighten the plane. There's some bad weather east of here. A heavy plane's dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her you're with the Dodgers. Jack would rather not play that card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When's the next flight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow morning. But it's booked. So someone'll have to cancel. Jack and Rachel unaware as a WHITE COUPLE are ushered out a door and onto the tarmac behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm with the Brooklyn Dodger organization. I've got to get down to Daytona. I'm supposed to report to spring training in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll do our best to get you down there by tomorrow afternoon, but it might be the day after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows her gaze to where the white couple get on the plane they got off. Jack wheels on Miss Bishop, furious. JACK You gave away our seats! Get us back on that plane! Miss Bishop picks up a PHONE, holds it in Jack's face. MISS BISHOP Do you want to call the Sheriff? Or should I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUS STATION - PENSACOLA - NIGHT 28 Closed. A line of EMPTY BUSES; the BANNER on one: Daytona Beach. Across from it Rachel sits at one end of a BENCH, her fur pulled around her. Jack at the other, staring off into the night. Finally, he reaches down, picks up the shoebox. He pulls out a DRUMSTICK, considers it, then takes a bite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama knew... He holds it out to Rachel. She slides over, takes it, takes a bite as well, smiles at him. He smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL FIELD - DAYTONA BEACH, FLORIDA - DAY 29 LEO DUROCHER hitting fungoes. One after the next. PEE WEE REESE and EDDIE STANKY both settle under the same ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it! I got it! I got it! I got it! They both back off at the last second and it drops to the ground between them. Durocher chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what spring training's for, boys! Sort out our differences! He hits another. This time to the outfield where veteran
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gives chase, finally gives up on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Dixie, get after it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm old!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna squeeze one more year out of that worn out body of yours!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you could, skipper, my wife would sure appreciate it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keeping the women happy! That's what it's all about!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./INT. CONVERTIBLE - DAY 29 A Rickey drives a dirt road through the training field singing aTwo Sleepy Peoplea along with the radio: Passing BROOKLYN DODGERS, MONTREAL ROYALS & ST. PAUL SAINTS on either side. Durocher hits another as Rickey pulls up. RICKEY How are they looking, Leo? DUROCHER Rusty, Mr. Rickey. But we'll get a em oiled up and ready in no time. You find your lost sheep yet? Troubled, Rickey shakes his head a no'. As he does, Harold Parrot hurries over. He's the Dodgers travelling secretary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie Robinson's on a bus leaving Pensacola.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bus? Harold, how in blazes did he end up on a bus?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in his catching gear, passing by with pitchers
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and KIRBY HIGBE. Higbe asides to Bragan: HIGBE Why don't they just put him on a watermelon truck?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with you guys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a thing, Branca, but we ain't just two pretty faces either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GREYHOUND STATION - DAYTONA BEACH - SUNSET 30 Wendell Smith stands waiting as a BUS pulls in. The big air brakes hiss. The doors open and the PASSENGERS disembark. First a DOZEN WHITE FACES, then a DOZEN BLACK. Last but not least, Rachel and Jack. They look exhausted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie Robinson... Mr. Rickey sent me to meet you. Wendell Smith. Pittsburgh Courier. I'm going to be your Boswell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your chronicler, your advance man. Hell, even your chauffeur. (tips his hat) Mrs. Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Rachel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man, you two look wiped out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got a car? Get us out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 31 EXT. SMITH'S BUICK (PARKED) - DAY 31 Jack and Smith carry the luggage. Smith's excited being around Jack even if he is grumpy. As Smith unlocks the Buick, Rachel considers a segregated pair of water fountains. SMITH You ever been down South before, Rachel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First time. We have our problems in Pasadena, but not like this. SMITH Mr. Rickey says we follow the law. If Jim Crow and the state of Florida say Negroes do this and that, then we do this and that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My life's changing right in front of me. Who I am, who I think I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE HARRIS HOUSE - DAYTONA BEACH - DAY 32 Black neighborhood. The Buick stops at a nice looking house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe and Duff Harris live here. He gets out the black vote, does a lot of good for colored folks. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rickey set it up himself. (IMITATES RICKEY) If we can't put the Robinsons in the hotels, they should stay some- place that represents something. Jack and Rachel exchange a look, the place seems nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brooklyn plays downtown; Montreal a few blocks from here. You'll stay with the Harrises except for a few days at the end of the week. The whole Dodger organization is going to Sanford, about 45 minute away. You'll stay here though, Rachel. RACHEL Where are the other wives staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are no other wives. You're the only one Mr. Rickey allowed to spring training. As the HARRISES step out on the porch, wave hello...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAIRWAY - THE HARRIS HOUSE - DAY 33 MRS. HARRIS leads Jack and Rachel up the stairs to a door at the top. Mrs. Harris opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HARRIS I call this the love nest. I hope you like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure. Thank you. As Jack enters, Mrs. Harris starts back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HARRIS Dinner's at five. Rachel enters, closes the door behind her -- 34 LOVE NEST 34 -- And accidentally knocks Jack onto the bed. She lands on top of him. The room is impossibly small. It barely holds their luggage and the BED they're on. As they look around:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a joke, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like it. The love nest. She kisses him. He's starting to like it, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remind me dinner's at five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try to remember... As the kisses become more urgent...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SMITH'S BUICK - DAYTONA TRAINING FACILITY - DAY A35 Smith pulls up alongside the team buses, looks across at Jack who is just a little nervous. SMITH The first day of Spring Training. My Pittsburgh Courier readers need to know how it feels. JACK It's okay. SMITH That's not exactly a headline. JACK (BRUSQUE) That's all I got. SMITH Look, Jack, right now it's just me asking you. But you get on that field and it's going to be the New York Times and the Sporting News. You should think about it. JACK If they ask something, I'll answer. SMITH Alright, but you know when you're at the plate, you want to feel like you see the pitch come in slow? Well, you want to see the questions come in slow, too. Jack just looks at him. Gets out. Smith sighs. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 26A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PLAYING FIELD - DODGERS DAYTONA FACILITY - DAY 35 As PLAYERS (Brooklyn, St. Paul & Montreal) warm up, practice, Rickey sits on the bench, angry as he reads a NEWSPAPER. Harold Parrott hurries over, something urgent on his mind. Rickey on a rant; Parrott can't get a word in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to this, Harold. Whenever I hear a white man - yours truly - broadcasting what a Moses he is to the Negro race, then I know the latter needs a bodyguard. (Parrott tries to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is those of the carpetbagger stripe of the white race - me again - who under the guise of helping, in truth are using the Negro for their own selfish interest, thereby retarding the race! Parrott tries to interrupt again, but Rickey is furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The minor league commissioner of baseball said that! I pay part of his salary! You wouldn't stab me in the back like this, would you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's here, Mr. Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you say so?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack crossing toward them in his Montreal Monarchs uniform carrying a glove and a bat. 200 white players clocking him. He's surrounded by REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS. It's the cue for most of the batting and fielding and chatter among the Dodgers, Royals and Saints to come to a stop. Higbe forgets Bragan is throwing him a ball. It clocks him in the chest. Reese and Stanky passing a medicine ball. REESE That's him, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a wild guess. Flash bulbs go off in Jack's face. Questions like punches. Shouts of a Jackie' and then... REPORTER ONE Jackie, do you think you can make it with these white boys? Jack looks off to where Smith watches, back to the reporter. See the questions slow. He answers with measure. JACK Sure, I had no problem with white men in the service or at UCLA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'll you do if one of these pitchers throws at your head?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (thinks a beat) I'll duck. That gets some laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, what's your natural position?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been playing shortstop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you after Pee Wee Reese's job?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jack looks over to where Reese watches with Stanky. JACK Reese plays for Brooklyn. I'm worried about making Montreal. REPORTER ONE Is this about politics?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about getting paid. Jack doing beautifully. Smith breathes a sigh of relief... YELLOW REV 4-24-12 28.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a Montreal uniform, Hopper's too old to be a ballplayer. He stands with Dixie Walker the Dodger right fielder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, when Mr. Rickey picks one, he sure picks a black one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's fine with me, so long as you keep him up in Montreal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes the old man to save him. They watch as Rickey pulls Jack from the press. He leads Jack directly toward Hopper. As Walker excuses himself...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, Hop...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, I'd like you to meet Jackie Robinson. Jackie, Clay Hopper, manager of the Montreal Royals. Hopper shakes his hand as they exchange greetings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We ain't doing much today. Just throwing the ball around and hitting a few. Why don't you toss a few with those fellas over there? (CALLS OVER) Hey, Jorgensen! A kid in a Montreal uniform looks over. SPIDER JORGENSEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meet Jackie Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PARKING LOT - DODGER DAYTONA FACILITY - DAY 37 The end of the day. Buses leave by team, the Dodgers and the farm clubs. White faces look down as they pass a tired Jack, who walks through the lot toward Wendell Smith and his Buick. Higbe and Bragan call out from the door of the Dodger bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Rook! Did you hear about the redneck shortstop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thought the last two words of the National Anthem were Play Ball! Jack forces a smile, but the joke comes off a bit harsh. And they seem like they're laughing at him as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about the shortstop making all the errors, tried to kill himself by jumping out on the highway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bus just missed him. Drove right between his legs! As the bus passes by, Jack sees the impassive faces of Dixie Walker, Reiser, Stanky, Pee Wee Reese and finally 20-year-old Branca. Branca smiles, offers an awkward little wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Between his legs, good one. He must've read a joke book. If he can read. Jack just gets in the car. Smith sighs, drum rolls the hood of the Buick. SMITH Hi, Wendell, how are you...? Well, looks like I got a long drive to Sanford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PORCH - THE BROCK HOUSE - SANFORD - LATE AFTERNOON 38 MR. BROCK comes out the screen door carrying a tray of tall drinks. He sets them on a table, watches and waits as Smith and Jack get out of the Buick, start up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK Jackie, I'm Ray Brock. Welcome to Sanford Florida! The day belongs to decent minded people. They shake hands. Brock looks to Smith, obviously knows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK Wendell, good to see you. (TO JACK) My wife's inside cooking. You know what she asked me this morning? She asked me, what do you serve when a hero's coming for dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jack's humble, embarrassed, doesn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just a ballplayer, Mr. Brock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK Tell that to all the little colored boys playing baseball in Florida today. You're a hero to them. The look on Jack's face says that's a heavy burden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK (CONT'D) Sit down, have something to drink. My special rum and coke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you, sir, I don't drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK A ballplayer who doesn't drink? That's a new one on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have one. I'm a stereotypical reporter through and through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Brock, do you have a desk? I'd like to get a letter to my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK Of course, this way. As Mr. Brock leads Jack ahead, Smith sips his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRACTICE DIAMOND - SANFORD - DAY 39 Rickey and Montreal manager Hopper stand by the dugout watching a spring game versus St Paul. Jack's playing second. They watch him closely as they talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's getting by on a quick release, but his arm's too weak for short. Second base is his spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree. And I'll state another obvious, Clay, I need the players to act like gentlemen around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The MAN on first takes a lead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To treat him as they would any other teammate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To be natural, to impose no restrictions on themselves. To all work together in harmony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! The hit & run is on. The man on first runs on the pitch as a LOW LINE DRIVE shoots for the gap between 1st and 2nd. Robinson turns himself inside out to dive on his belly and catch it before it hits the ground. He spins himself around, pivots on a knee to throw the runner out before he can get back to first. A  Rickey is astounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was superhuman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Superhuman? Don't get carried away, Mr. Rickey, that's still a Nigger out there. Rickey takes a moment to process. It's Hopper's light admonishing tone that really halts him. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, I realize that attitude is part of your heritage; that you practically nursed race prejudice at your mother's breast, so I will let it pass. But I will add this: you can manage Robinson fairly and correctly or you can be unemployed. They both look over as Jack comes off the field toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attaboy, Jackie! Way to turn two!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FRONT PORCH - THE BROCK HOUSE - SANFORD - NIGHT 40 Smith and Mr. Brock are sitting on the porch sipping rum and cokes. A quiet evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLUE REV 7-9-12 32.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK I hope Jackie sleeps alright. Chasing baseballs in the sun all day, I'd be in my grave. How are they treating him out there? They watch as a CAR slows, parks across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay as far as I can see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: exits the car and starts toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK (FROWNS) You find good people every place you go. Even here in Florida...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is it you're looking for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nigra ball player. The air suddenly alive with danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's asleep. Maybe you better come back in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't comin' back. Other fellas is comin'. They ain't too happy about him stayin' here in Sanford. Playin' ball with white boys. (a long beat) Skedaddle, that's what I'd do. If'n they get here, and he's still here, there's gonna be trouble. He turns and walks away. As they watch, a phone rings...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Wendell, what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL ROOM - DAYTONA BEACH - NIGHT 41 Rickey in his pajamas in his hotel room. On the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see... Yes, I understand. Wake him up and get him out of there. Put him in the car and start driving for Daytona Beach. Now. And, Wendell, under no circumstance tell him what this is about. I do not want him to get it in his head to stay there and fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - MR. BROCK'S HOUSE - NIGHT 42 Half dressed, Jack sits on the edge of his bed, feeling bad. Through his open door, across a hall, we can see Smith in his room. Passing in and out of view packing his own things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just getting loose. Smith sticks his head in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't just sit there. Pack your duds. We're blowin'. A phone RINGS somewhere. They hear Brock answer, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROCK'S VOICE Wendell?! Smith leaves the room. Hold on Jack, despair as he listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Rickey, I'm with him now... We're pulling out for Daytona in five minutes, soon as he gets his bag packed... Yes, yes, it's just one of those things. a One of those things.' As Jack's head hangs a little lower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./EXT. BUICK - MAIN STREET - SANFORD - NIGHT 43 The street deserted, sidewalks rolled up. Jack angry and silent in the passenger seat. Smith jumpy behind the wheel. They stop as a PICK-UP stops ahead outside a BAR where:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in shirtsleeves exchange words with the boys in the truck. To Jack it looks like a typical small town bull session. To Smith it looks like something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The white men look over at the two black men. One steps over, motions: roll down the window. JACK I wonder what he wants? SMITH To run us out of town. JACK What are you talking about? The man close now. As Jack cranks down the window, Smith floors it. The Buick SCREECHES away, SWERVING around a CAR coming the other way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell, Wendell?! SMITH Man came by while you were asleep. (CHECKS MIRROR) Told us more men were coming. Maybe those boys. Mr. Rickey said to get you to Daytona Beach a-s-a-p.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you say so? SMITH Mr. Rickey was afraid you wouldn't leave, that you would fight. As it becomes clear, Jack starts to LAUGH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell are you laughing at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you woke me because I was cut from the team. Jack LAUGHS harder. Wendell LAUGHS as well. As it fades, Jack looks back over his shoulder. Jesus...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CITY ISLAND BALLPARK - DAYTONA BEACH - DAY 44 A stadium SIGN boasts Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Montreal Royals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Daytona Beach's black community is turning out to see Jackie Robinson. Hundreds of people line up, mass at the: Colored Entrance. In their Sunday best. Families. Couples. The old. The frail. Young boys chase after each other. One
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands on her toes to spot her son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed! You stay where I can see you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: year old ED CHARLES turns, waves his baseball glove over his head so she can see him. Then to no one in particular:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm thirteen years old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enter at several gates around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE DODGER DUGOUT 45 He sits watching as the segregated bleachers in right fill with BLACK FANS. All else is white. Rickey pops a PEANUT in his mouth, confides to someone alongside him we don't see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've spoken to the mayor. I've explained how much money we'll spend in Daytona. But still, when this fine young Negro man steps on that field today, he and the Dodgers will technically be breaking the law. A law which says white and black players cannot enjoy the same field at the same time. Does that make sense to you? Does Jim Crow make any sense when placed against the words of the United States Constitution? When placed against the word of God?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to reveal he sits beside the DODGER BATBOY, so short his feet don't touch the ground. Rickey offers his peanut bag. As the batboy takes one...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you, it does not make sense to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ON DECK CIRCLE - CITY ISLAND BALLPARK - DAY 49 Jack swinging two bats to get loose. Watches as the Montreal
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hits a LINE DRIVE which -- Pee Wee Reese nearly leaps out of his socks to bring down. Wow... As the CROWD claps in appreciation, Jack takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now batting the second baseman -- Jackie Robinson! Jack wincing as he steps forward to both cheers and boos from the white sections. As a a go home, coon' drifts over -- A BIG OVATION from the black section in right drowns it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RIGHT FIELD Rachel sits with Smith. They react to some of the INVECTIVE coming from the white section. RACHEL Jack's got a thick skin. He'll be okay. SMITH How about you? RACHEL (SHRUGS) I better get one in a hurry. INFIELD Higbe watching from the mound as Jack steps into the batter's box. Two well wishing voices from the infield stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, black boy, you can make the grade!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're giving you a chance! Do something about it! Jack heartened at the words. Concentrates as Higbe's first pitch is fired. High and tight, Jack jerks out of the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bragan, behind the plate, chucks the ball back, grins up at Jack who does not look down at him as he settles back in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 13-year-old holding his hands together in prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, God, let Jackie show them what we can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes the next pitch. Even tighter. Jack nearly hit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ball two! Jack glaring, crowds the plate more. Bragan shows 1, taps his right thigh signalling outside. Jack watches it sail, doesn't bite. The umpire: aBall Three!a Higbe's fun slipping away as he can't find the strike zone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rook! Ain't you gonna swing at something?! Jack takes a practice swing, waits as Bragan sets up right over the plate. Here comes the pitch. Low. aBall four!a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big, over-reacting CHEER from the Colored section.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just a walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who can blame them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks ill-tempered over to first where Jack gives the same look back as he sidesteps an enormous, defiant lead off the bag. Higbe incredulous. Did he just do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well throw over there for crying out loud! Higbe fires to LAVAGETTO at first. Jack dives back in time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Higbe gets the ball back, settles. Jack takes a lead, but a modest one this time. Here come the pitch -- And Jack goes. You knew he was fast; but not this fast. Bragan's throw to Pee Wee is late and high. Pee Wee throws back to Higbe. Higbe sets. Bragan gives him a sign. Jack takes a lead. On the wind-up, Jack goes. Bragan stands -- it's a PITCH OUT. Bragan fires to third and Jack is caught in a RUN DOWN. It seems like half the team gets involved with Higbe finally getting the ball by third and Jack ducking under the tag. Safe! A BUZZ goes through the stadium now as people start to realize they are not watching something or someone ordinary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching from a seat behind third.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thataway, Jackie! Thataway!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Higbe looks home for the sign, Jack dancing off third, pounding his right foot toward home. He feints hard home. Higbe steps off the rubber. Jack stays where he is. HIGBE Hell! You're supposed to go back to third when I step off! Don't you know nothing?! He throws over. Jack back to the bag. Higbe gets the ball back, looks in. Jack bouncing, pounding off third. His movements carry violence within them. Like a piston exploding in an engine. Higbe into his motion, stops his delivery, accidentally drops the ball to the ground. The umpire signals BALK, points Jack home. Higbe is furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - IN THE COLORED SECTION CHEERING, joyous. His mother joins in, happy despite...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand. What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a balk, Mama. The pitcher can't start toward home and then stop. Jackie scores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he didn't do anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, mama, yes he did, he discombobulated the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Durocher looks to Branca, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't come to play; he came to kill. Durocher starts out to the mound to talk to Higbe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching from right field, the black crowd still cheering. He walks over toward the open bullpen where Casey stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This really how it's gonna be some day? Baseball?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCOREBOARD - BALLFIELD - DAY 50 Montreal vs. Indianapolis. THE STANDS are half filled. The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is packed solid, accentuated by the many empty seats in the sections on either side of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : De Land, Florida. No score, top of the first as -- Jack drops a BUNT down the line. The FIRST BASEMAN fields, throw to the SECOND BASEMAN covering. Too late. Only Jack doesn't stop. Realizing the SHORTSTOP isn't covering the bag, Jack bolts for second. The second baseman has to wait on the throw and when he makes it -- The UMPIRE signals safe. A bunt double! Spider Jorgensen settles in the batter's box. The pitch. Crack, Jorgensen laces a single to left. Jack motors to third where Sukeforth is WAVING him home. We're with him at hip level as he tears down the basepath. The CATCHER bracing for the throw - they COLLIDE - he's SAFE! As Jack gets to his feet, however, a Jim Crow POLICEMAN steps up to meet him, grabs him by the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Git offa this field now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What!? Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's against the law is why. No niggers don't play with no white boys. Git off or go to jail. Jack shrugs the policeman's hand off his shoulder. That sends him reaching for his nightstick and -- Sukeforth is there to get between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You swing that thing you better hit me between the eyes with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that so? The CROWD BOOING. The black section especially.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (arrives from dugout) Hey, hold on, what'd he do wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We ain't havin' Nigras mix with white boys in this town. Ya'll ain't up-states now; they gotta stay separate. Brooklyn Dodgers ain't changing our way of living. Where are you all from anyhow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greenwood, Mississippi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, man, you oughta know better. (a dangerous beat) Now tell your Nigra I said to git. You think I'm foolin'? Hopper looks desperately to Jack who just stands there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAYTONA BEACH - HARRIS NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY 51 Jack and Rachel out walking. He's been telling the story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said okay, Skipper, tell him... Ah'm a-gittin'. Sho'nuff, ah is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did. Then I took a long shower. We lost 2 to 1. She takes a few exaggerated steps to amuse him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah'm a-gittin', ah'm a gittin'. He laughs, takes her hand. He's going to kiss her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not getting away from me. RACHEL (LOOKING PAST) Jack... A white man bee-lines them from across the street, looks like a real CRACKER. Jack on guard, gets in front of Rachel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back, Rae. Go back. Cracker stops square across from him. Jack's fists balled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to know something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, what's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to know I'm pulling for you to make good. And a lot of folks here feel the same way. If a man's got the goods, he deserves a fair chance. That's all. (tips his hat) Ma'am. As Cracker walks away... Rachel takes Jack's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PLAYING FIELD - DODGER DAYTONA FACILITY - DAY 52A Rickey leans against his car watching a GROUNDSKEEPER push mow the infield grass. Jack, in street clothes, joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wanted to see me, Mr. Rickey? Rickey nods, consider the field a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like the way it smells when they mow it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too. Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack. RICKEY Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't let you down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't mind, I've got to go tell my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you believe that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think what I believe is important. Only what I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agreed. Therefore, run the bases like the Devil himself. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worry those pitchers so they come apart. Sometimes they'll catch you, but don't worry about that. Ty Cobb got caught plenty. Just run as you see fit. Put the natural fear of God into them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAYTONA BEACH TRAIN STATION - DAY 53 Ed Charles and his TWO FRIENDS follow Jack and the Montreal
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they walk toward the TRAIN waiting on the tracks. Jack is one of the last to board. He's almost through the door when something stops him. He looks back at Ed. A beat. Ed slowly raises his hand and waves. Jack smiles, does the same, then disappears inside. The WHISTLE blows and the train starts out of the station. On impulse Ed starts to trot out after it. Staying close. His friends follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train picks up speed. The boys start to run. Arms pumping, feet flying. One boy drops off. Then the other. But Ed still runs. Chasing after that train carrying Jackie Robinson. Finally, he stops, heaving for breath, watching the train disappear around the bend. A lonely beat. Then -- Ed gets down on his hands and knees. He sets his ear on the rail, closes his eyes. A thrum comes off the rail. A huge smile spreads. He straightens, shouts back to his friends:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! From somewhere, as the National Anthem ends...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ED I CAN STILL HEAR HIM

direction.raw_text: . ROOSEVELT STADIUM - DAY 54 INSERT: April 18, 1946 - Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City. Opening day of the International League Season.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: march away to REVEAL: HOME PLATE UMPIRE PLAY BALL!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pack a stadium built for 24,500. Bunting and flags everywhere. 1000s of black fans are here (segregated only financially in New Jersey).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOME PLATE - ROOSEVELT STADIUM - DAY 55 Jack steps up to some BOOING, but much more APPLAUSE. He looks ready to beat the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : First inning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jackie, this fella can't pitch! Speaking of the pitch, here it comes. Jack tops a WEAK GROUNDER to short. As he's thrown out by a mile...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & RACHEL 56 Sitting up off third. His knees knocked together to hold his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on his lap. Nothing to write about there. He looks over at Rachel who puts her hand over her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I might be sick. (STANDING) Excuse me, Wendell. He watches as she starts out, looks to the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be sick at a swing like that, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . REST ROOM STALL - ROOSEVELT STADIUM - DAY 57 Rachel exits looking stricken. She steps over, splashes a little water from the sink up into her face. An OLDER BLACK WOMAN watches sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright, honey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sick. I don't know why. The older woman rolls off a piece of paper towel for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you have your monthly last?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rachel looks over, taken aback. But then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It may be that you're pregnant. The older woman offers a little smile, leaves her there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Third Inning. P.A. ANNOUNCER (ECHOING) Now batting. Jackie Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack steps up to bat. The JERSEY CITY GIANT PITCHER looks to the Montreal RUNNER at first, glances over his shoulder at the Montreal RUNNER at second, then focuses on home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hands resting on the top of his typewriter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jackie. Come on, batter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emerging up the runway. The field opening up before her. There's Jack standing down there. The sight of him settles her. As she puts a hand gently over her belly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grimaces for something extra as he fires a high fastball -- Jack UNLOADS. All heads turn to watch it sail -- high into the left field bleachers, banging hard off the scoreboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nearly drops his typewriter, pushes his hat back as he watches Jack start his home run trot. Smith laughs. Joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hopper can't believe his eyes. Softly to himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be damned...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he runs the base paths. Over it, a TYPEWRITER CLATTERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Robinson jogged around the bases, his heart singing... The crowd loves it as he continues toward third where Sukeforth is clapping for all he's worth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (CONT'D) And our own hearts beat just a bit faster, and the thrill ran through us like champagne bubbles...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching him head for home, shaking hands with the two men he batted in. Pride & joy in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jack... Oh Jack...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly in pain, face beaded in sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack! Jack!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : November 18, 1946. Pasadena, California. She is in labor and we are in Huntington Memorial Hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The DOCTOR holds up a slick, wailing NEWBORN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a boy. As Rachel holds out her arms for him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - MATERNITY WARD - PASADENA - NIGHT 67 Jack at the glass looking at JACKIE JR. Jack's eyes shine as he regards his infant son. It's quiet. Jack's voice soft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daddy left. He left us flat in Cairo, Georgia. I was only six months older than you are now. I don't remember him. Nothing good, nothing bad. Nothing. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're going to remember me. And I am going to be with you until the day I die. The stakes just got raised...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . YMCA GYMNASIUM - DAY 68 THIRTY prominent BROOKLYN NEGRO leaders, representing a cross section of civic responsibility, sit on folding chairs before a dais where HERBERT MILLER making an introduction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As all of us know a young Negro second baseman played north of the border last season...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Brooklyn YMCA. February 5, 1947. In back: TWO DEACONS in the back whisper over a SPORTS PAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look here what he did. (READS) Led the International League in batting: .349, in stolen bases: 40, runs scored: 113. Plus batted .400 in the Minor League World Series.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last season doesn't matter. The International League, it doesn't matter. What matters is this year. What matters is Brooklyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhh... Here he comes. As Herbert Miller introduces...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I present the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodger baseball club, Mr. Branch Rickey! Warm APPLAUSE as Rickey steps up. As it settles...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us. (A BEAT) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a ballplayer on my Montreal team named Jackie Robinson. The start of applause. Rickey motions for it to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a group of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on: RICKEY I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this! (pounds his fist) If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - YMCA - DAY 69 Rickey stands waiting; giving that speech has worn him out. The door opens and Miller looks in on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I question your bedside manner, Mr. Rickey, but they've agreed to set up a committee of self-policing. We'll call it the 'Don't Spoil Jackie's Chances' campaign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - BEVERLY HILLS HOTEL SUITE - NIGHT 70 The silhouette of stately palms through the window. A PHONE RINGS. A figure fumbles through silk sheets for the receiver. It's LEO DUROCHER, a WOMEN in bed alongside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Beverly Hills. February 16, 1947.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Leo, what are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm bowling. Wait, I'm snowshoeing in the Alps. I'm trying to sleep, Mr. Rickey. It's still dark out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - EARLY MORNING 71 It's very early in New York. Rickey on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE FOLLOWING: 72 DUROCHER I don't got an attitude toward him. The girl rolls over to look at him. She is the actress
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and she is stunning. As Durocher regards her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She puts her hands on him. (Durocher addressing Rickey.) LORRAINE (SOFTLY) Hi... DUROCHER I don't know much about the Bible. LORRAINE Me neither... DUROCHER But I didn't go to school just to eat my lunch either. I'll play an elephant if he can help us win. To make room for him, I'll send my own brother home if he's not as good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in his ear) What are you going to do with me? DUROCHER We're playing for money, Mr. Rickey. Winning's the only thing that matters. Is he a nice guy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. He can't afford to be. Nice guys finish last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about nice girls? She starts to kiss him. It's hard to concentrate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you have no objections to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None whatsoever. Can I go back to sleep now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Oh -- and Leo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure it's got a lot to say about a lot. Good night. Durocher hangs up the phone, looks to her. DUROCHER What am I gonna do with you? LORRAINE Leo, I thought you knew... As she kisses him... CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PEPPER STREET - PASADENA - DAY 73 Jack stands out front kissing Jackie Jr. good-bye as a CABBIE muscles his LUGGAGE down the walkway to a waiting TAXI. Jack kisses Mallie and hands off the baby. Mallie carries the boy inside leaving Jack and Rachel alone to say goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Promise me you'll write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did I ever not write?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to know I'm there for you. Even if it's words on paper. He's sees she's raw, takes her in his arms with the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rae, you're in my heart. She sighs, rests her head on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're getting close now. The closer you get, the worse they'll be. Don't let them get to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not. God built me to last. He kisses her. She kisses him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you in Brooklyn in eight weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It might be Montreal. A certainty grips her. She passes it on to him. RACHEL It's going to be Brooklyn. I know it is. Power in her words. He nods, looks off toward the taxi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to go, Rae. She nods. They kiss, embrace a last time. He starts away down the walk. She watches. Something not quite right. A tug as Jack stops, looks back at her. Fighting back her emotion and then impelled forward, she runs to him. They come together. She practically disappears in his arms. They do not want to be apart. CUT TO: WHITE 3-14-12 52.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM - THE TIVOLI HOTEL - DAY 74 Durocher eats heartily. Rickey's food is untouched.
