direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a pipe dream, Mr. Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Panama City, Panama. March 18, 1947.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean it ain't gonna happen. The Dodgers are never gonna demand Robinson be brought up from Montreal. Ball players are conservative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It - ain't - gonna - happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not saying they won't accept him: I'm saying they won't ask for him. I'm saying Robinson's good medicine, but they're not gonna like the taste. I'm saying bend over, boys, and get ready, this one might hurt a little. (ANOTHER FORKFUL) Boy, this is good fish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - IN HIS TIVOLI HOTEL ROOM 75 As Higbe (South Carolina) finishes WRITING something on a piece of hotel STATIONARY, Bragan (Alabama) looks to Dixie Walker (Alabama) and Dodger pitcher HUGH CASEY (Georgia).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you think Rickey's got us playing spring games in Panama? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants to get us used to Negro crowds. He wants more of them than us. He's hoping it'll get us more comfortable being around Robinson. Higbe clears his throat, reads what he's written:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We, the undersigned Brooklyn Dodgers will not play ball on the same field as Jackie Robinson. Higbe signs it. He hands the pen to Bragan who adds his own name. Casey signs with a flourish. Casey holds out the pen to Walker who doesn't take it right away. An odd beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you wanna make your mark, Dixie, we can witness it. Everyone laughs; it loosens Walker up enough to sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Higbe KNOCKS as Casey, Bragan and Walker crowd behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon in!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys enter. Eddie Stanky sits in a chair stripped to the waist, soaking his right elbow in a BUCKET OF ICE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's goin' on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got a petition goin' on, Stank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To keep Robinson up in Montreal where he belongs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... Did Pee Wee sign it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ain't asked him yet. What difference does it make?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None, just wonderin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Stanky looks to Walker who looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re: his right arm) Can't sign now. I'm indisposed. Could I catch up with you later?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing in the door to his room. Looking out at the glum faces of Higbe, Bragan, Casey and Walker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, it's like this. I got a wife, a baby, and I got no money. I don't want to step in anything. (TO WALKER) Skip me, Dix, I'm not interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if they put him at shortstop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's man enough to take my job, I suppose he deserves it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughs out loud) The hell he does!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does not have the ice water in his veins for big league baseball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So let him show what he's got. Robinson can play or he can't. It'll all take care of itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The very son of immigrants Rickey was talking about. From Pennsylvania no less.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me the pen. Higbe grins, hands it over. As Furillo signs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEO DUROCHER'S ROOM - THE TIVOLI HOTEL - NIGHT 79 Durocher lays staring up at the palm shadows on the ceiling. Finally, the phone rings. He answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Rickey. RICKEY'S VOICE Have our friends in the press gone to sleep yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are the only people awake on this entire isthmus, Mr. Rickey. RICKEY'S VOICE A deliberate violation of the law, needs a little show of force. I leave it to you. Good night, Leo. DUROCHER Yes, Mr. Rickey. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL KITCHEN - NIGHT 80 Deserted. Durocher stands in a hotel bathrobe, arms crossed as his PLAYERS and COACHES file in. Bleary-eyed, half- dressed, they're all here, all wondering what this is about. Suddenly, Durocher grabs the handle of an industrial-sized
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and heaves it across the room. BRWANG-RANG-RANG!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up, ladies! Wake the Hell up! (a stunned beat) It's come to my attention that some of you fellas don't want to play with Robinson. That you even got a petition drawn up that you're all gonna sign. Well boys, you know what you can do with your petition?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Leo...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on what?!
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: YOU CAN WIPE YOUR ASSES WITH IT
result.heading: YOU CAN WIPE YOUR ASSES WITH IT

direction.raw_text: Ball players gotta live together, shower together, it's not right to force him on us. Besides, I own a hardware store back home and I -- PINK REV 4-19-12 56.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Screw your hardware store, Dix! And if you don't like it, screw you! Mr. Rickey'll be happy to make other arrangements for you. Durocher suddenly marches to Higbe, looks like he's going to belt him. As Higbe gulps, Durocher turns to the team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care if he's yellow or black or has stripes like a zebra, if Robinson can help us win, and everything I've seen says he can, then he's gonna play on this ball club. Like it, lump it, make your mind up to it because he's coming! And think about this when your heads hit the pillow, he's only the first, boys, only the first. More are coming right behind him. They have talent and they wanna play! He lets that sink a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir, they're gonna come diving and scratching. So I'd forget your petition and worry about the field. Because unless you fellas pay a little more attention to your work, they are going to run you right out of the ball park! A petition? (looks them over) Are you ballplayers or lawyers? As he marches past them and through the doors...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./INT. DUGOUT - PANAMA PRACTICE FIELD - DAY 84 Jack in his Montreal uniform headed off the field for the dugout. Sukeforth headed over wearing Dodger blue. SUKEFORTH Robinson! As Jack turns, Sukeforth tosses him a FIRST BASEMAN'S GLOVE. JACK What do you want me to do with this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Play first base.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never played first base in my life, Coach. SUKEFORTH Well, it's like this. Brooklyn's got a solid second baseman. And they got Pee Wee Reese at short. But first base is up for grabs. Are you catching my drift?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I don't need a glove to do that. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PRACTICE FIELD 86 Coach Sukeforth, getting balls from a bucket, hitting grounders down to Jack at first. The short hops are wicked. Jack rolls his catches over to a little PANAMANIAN KID who chucks them down to his brother who tosses them back to Sukeforth. As Jack struggles... PANAMANIAN KID El es muy malo. SUKEFORTH Mr. Rickey said he wants you playing conspicuous baseball! (WHACK) To be so good the Dodgers'll demand you on the team! (WHACK) So I thought about it awhile and then I looked up conspicuous in the dictionary. (WHACK) It means to attract notice or attention. Jack dives, spears a liner. Sukeforth tilts back his cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Conspicuous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RICKEY'S OFFICE - THE TIVOLI HOTEL - DAY 89 Bobby Bragan sits across from Rickey looking defiant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Sir. My friends back in Birmingham would never forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your friends here in Brooklyn? (Bragan just shrugs) Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think I would quit on anyone?! I don't quit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PANAMA - DAY 89A Time slowed way down as Jack takes a throw at second from the Montreal shortstop. He pivots to turn the double-play even as Dixie Walker barrels in low. All Jackie's focus on the task at hand as he throws while Walker submarines him. He lands in a heap tangled up together. They both look back to see the result of the play. As Robinson smiles and Walker scowls, we know... RICKEY'S VOICE Send Dixie in. CUT TO: BLUE REV 4-07-12 60.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sitting down across from Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I received your letter, Dixie. (READS) Recently, the thought has occurred to me that a change of ball clubs would benefit both the Brooklyn Baseball Club and myself. (TO WALKER) This is about Robinson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm keeping my reasons private. Hope you can respect that, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I have, Mr. Rickey, is a hardware store back home. It's called Dixie Walker's. Folks don't come because I have the lowest prices, they come because it's called Dixie Walker's. Understand? And I make as much money owning that store as I do playing for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that what you're you afraid of? (he doesn't answer) Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got my letter; can I go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always have. That's my job. CUT TO: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 61.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PENN STATION - NIGHT 91 INSERT: Manhattan. April 8, 1947. Jack exits with his luggage. Looking for a cab, he sees Smith waiting. Smith offers a salute. Jack looks grumpy as he steps over. The Buick waiting beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You again. Smith leans back, blinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Me again. Something wrong with that, Jack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Jack continues past. As Smith follows...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SMITH'S BUICK - 34TH STREET - NIGHT 92 Traffic heavy. A glum silence in the car until...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can't keep you on Montreal for long. After these exhibition games, they've got to bring you up. (NO REPLY) You don't have two words to rub together, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I have to entertain you? More silence, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ever wonder why I sit out in right field with my typewriter on my knees? Does that ever cross your mind? Jack stares out the passenger window, not in the mood. As he looks up at some of the taller buildings they pass...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's because Negro reporters aren't allowed in the press box. Jack doesn't answer, doesn't look over. Finally Smith starts talking to himself. Pretending to be Jack. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 62.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a AS JACK' You know, Wendell, I never asked you where you were from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why I'm from Detroit, Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a AS JACK' You don't say? Tell me more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daddy used to work at Fair Lane. That was Mr. Ford's estate. My daddy was Mr. Henry Ford's cook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a AS JACK' I did not know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooked for him for years, but never once broke bread with him. I'd go to work with daddy sometimes. Play baseball out on the lawn with Mr. Ford's grandchildren. We all had a real good time. But it was understood, if they got tired of playing ball and moved inside to the bowling alley or swimming pool, I was not invited or allowed. The grass was as far as I got. So guess what? You're not the only one with something at stake here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) If I start talking, will you stop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be happy to. Smith stops at a red light. JACK I apologize. You've been there for me through this more than anyone besides Rae and Mr. Rickey. But I guess that's what bothers me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like needing someone to be there for me. I don't like needing anyone but myself. I never have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a hard case, Jack Robinson. Is it okay if I keep driving you or should I let you out so you can walk? Jack bursts out laughing. So does Smith. JACK You remember the last time we were at a red light? Down in Florida? SMITH New York City now, baby. We've come a long way. JACK And we got a long way to go. The light turns green. Off they go. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 93 Rickey reads to Parrott from the New York Sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Brooklyn. April 9, 1947.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal. (throws paper down) For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you could have Durocher hold a press conference. Demand that he get Robinson on his team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Durocher. Of course, he's my ace in the hole. Very good, Harold. The phone still rings. Rickey looks to his open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Ann! Are you out there? Grumbling, brambly eyebrows twitching, he makes the mistake of answering his own phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch Rickey... You're speaking to him... The Commissioner of what..? Oh, yes put him on. (looks to Parrott) The commissioner of baseball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE - DAY 94 HAPPY CHANDLER gets a manicure. Always jovial, a head like an anvil with hair parted in the middle, he picks up a phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch, how are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. What can I do for you, Happy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch, how would you feel about losing Durocher for a year? Rickey switches the phone from one ear to the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Happy, I thought you said lose Durocher for a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He was seen in Havana with known gamblers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone who sets foot in Havana is seen with known gamblers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not just one thing, it's an accumulation. I received notice today from the Catholic Youth Organization. Vowing a ban on baseball unless Durocher is punished for his moral looseness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're joking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's this business with the actress in California. She's recently divorced and Durocher is the cause. They may even be illegally married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I'm sure you're joking. Happy checks his nails, returns his hand to the MANICURIST.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I were. The CYO buy a lot of tickets, Branch. They draw a lot of water and I can't afford to ruffle their feathers. Am I mixing metaphors there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know very well my organization is about to enter a tempest. I need Durocher at the rudder. He's the only man who can handle this much trouble, who loves it in fact. You're chopping off my right hand!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no choice. I'm going to have to sit your manager, Branch. Leo Durocher is suspended from baseball for a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't do that! Happy, you son of a bitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rickey steadies himself, looks to Parrott.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trouble ahead, Harold. Trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DODGER LOCKER ROOM - EBBETS FIELD - DAY 95 Durocher, in a suit, cleans out his locker. Carefully sets each item in a cardboard box. Finished, he closes the locker door. CLICK. And then -- WHAM! -- Drives his fist in, taking it off its hinges. He picks up his box, quietly walks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PINK REV 4-19-12 66.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MCALPIN HOTEL ROOM - EARLY MORNING 99A RING... Jack asleep in bed, fumbles for the receiver. INSERT: April 10, 1947. JACK Hello? JANE ANN'S VOICE Mr. Robinson, this is Jane Ann in Mr. Rickey's office. He needs to see you right away. He has a contract for you to sign. That wakes him up. CUT TO: 99B INT. BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 99B Jack sits at the desk. Alone. He looks back over his shoulder at the GOLDFISH. As one of them stares back, Rickey enters with the CONTRACT in question. He sets it down before Jack, hands him a pen. RICKEY I'm so sorry about the rush. Events are unfolding too fast to keep up with. The burden has finally fallen to me and so be it. JACK (POINTS) Sign here? RICKEY Yes, yes. As Jack poises the pen -- Rickey suddenly aghast. RICKEY Stop! The pen a millimeter over the page. RICKEY History. And I'm blabbing, blabbing through history... Rushing it along. What am I thinking? TAN REV 6-25-12 66A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rickey sticks his head out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Ann, come in here. (hollering down hall) Harold! Parrott sticks his head out from an office down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get some employees up here! CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where Jack Robinson signs his contract. As he sets the pen down -- Rickey starts APPLAUDING. He's joined by Parrott,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and a JANITOR. Rickey claps Jack on the shoulder. RICKEY Harold, telegram the press. Say this: aThe Brooklyn Dodgers today purchased the contract of Jackie Robinson from the Montreal Royals. He will report immediately.a As Jack takes it in, he's the only one not smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - ISUM HOUSE - PASADENA - DAWN 99E The phone rings. Rachel answers in her nightgown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rae, I'm in Brooklyn. Brooklyn... Rachel lets out a triumphant WHOOP!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did I tell you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHTSCAPE - NEW YORK MIDTOWN SKYLINE - NIGHT 100 A few lights twinkle, but this city does occasionally sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This man does not. He stands bare chested in his boxers staring out the window of a MCALPIN HOTEL ROOM. Considering the world before him. Wondering where his place is in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : April 15, 1947. 3 AM. It's a lonely moment. Until Rachel appears behind him in her nightgown. She wraps her arms around him, looks over his shoulder at the world out there. Finally, softly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you... As he closes his eyes, absorbs it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AISLE - SINGER'S DRUG STORE - BROOKLYN - DAY 102 Jack cruises down, stops in front of the PEPTO BISMOL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : April 15, 1947. 11 AM. As he grabs a bottle -- a man on the other side pulls one out as well. Jack finds himself looking at Pee Wee Reese.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SINGER'S DRUG STORE - BROOKLYN - DAY 103 Jack and Reese exit together, each with a bottle of Pepto Bismol in hand. Reese hefts his bottle. REESE Opening day nerves. Doing my stomach something awful. Jack nods in commiseration. It's awkward between them. A RUMBLE as a GARBAGE TRUCK goes by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There goes another one. (SMILES) Every time I see a garbage truck go by I still can't figure why the guy driving isn't me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd both better get on base. Reese nods. They start walking toward the stadium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know when I first heard of you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a troop transport, coming back from Guam. A sailor heard it on the radio, told me the Dodgers had signed a Negro player. I said that was fine by me. Then he said the guy was a shortstop. Least you were then. That got me thinking. Thinking gets me scared. Jack smiles, hefts his bottle of Pepto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Black, white, we're both pink today, huh? (REESE NODS) You still scared, Pee Wee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looks down street) Of garbage trucks? Terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EBBETS STADIUM - DAY 103A The Taj Mahal of baseball. Opening day. INSERT: Ebbets Field. Brooklyn. CUT TO: 104 INT. DODGER LOCKER ROOM - DAY 104 Some guys quiet, some guys joking around. Everyone in some version of getting out of their street clothes or into their uniforms. The entire operation comes to a halt as -- Jack enters. As he walks past -- some players nod hello. Others look like Sphinxes. Walker turns and faces his locker. Gene Hermanski and Branca step over to SHAKE HANDS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Hermanski. Welcome to Brooklyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, man. Ralph Branca. Last, but not least, Spider Jorgensen, his Montreal teammate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We made it, Jack, huh? Good luck. That's it. Everyone else is too busy to come over. As Jack scans for a locker with his name on it, BABE HAMBURGER, the clubhouse manager, steps over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking for your locker, huh, kid? Follow me. They walk over to a hook on the wall. A uniform hangs from it. A FOLDING CHAIR below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just got the word. Best I could do. I'll get you straightened out tomorrow though, huh? Jack nods, unbuttoning his shirt... Stanky is suddenly there. All pugnacity as he gives up 4 inches and 40 pounds to Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're putting on that uniform, it means you're on my team. But before I play with you I want you to know how I feel about it. I want you to know I don't like it. I want you to know I don't like you. Jack regards him. Stanky doesn't flinch. Maybe he should.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fine. That's how I prefer it. Right out in the open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EBBETS FIELD 105 Standing before his steaming HOT DOG STAND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Brooklyn! Get your Harry M. Stevens special here! As he hands one over, gets his .20 cents in return. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Lady! Rachel looks over, baby Jackie in her arms. The vendor takes a baby bottle out of the hot water in his STEAMER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DODGER CLUBHOUSE 106 Looking at himself in a MIRROR. Standing in his uniform, the clean white wool, the flowing script: Dodgers. It fits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We FOLLOW HIM past Stanky as he goes. Follow the BLUE 42 on his back as he steps through the clubhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 107 Always on that magic number as he comes up through the Dodger
direction.name: direction

result.heading: 107 MAKES HIS WAY UP THE TUNNEL

direction.raw_text: and steps onto...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: snap photos, the crowd spot him and CHEER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watches from the stands. Pleased at the cheering. She holds the baby up to see, whispers to him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, okay, that's good. As Jackie's eyes find hers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Dodgers down one baseline, the BOSTON BRAVES down the other. Forty-nine white players and one black. Jack at the end alongside Ralph Branca. Jack trying not to choke up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: O'er the land of the free! And the home of the brave!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: 110 THE PLAYERS LINED UP FOR THE NATIONAL ANTHEM 110

direction.raw_text: . DODGER DUGOUT - DAY 111 The players not starting return to the dugout. Bragan catches up with Branca.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy standing that close to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if the sharpshooter misses and hits you instead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got a serious problem, Bragan, you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? I don't see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surveying the scene. Parrott alongside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Opening day, Harold. The world is all future and no past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A blank page, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROADCAST BOOTH - EBBETS FIELD - DAY 113 RED BARBER looks down onto the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One out in the bottom of the first. Headed toward the plate for his first big league at bat is Dodger rookie Jackie Robinson. Jackie is very definitely brunette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walks toward the plate. More cheers. Mostly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're with you, Jackie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, boy, how about a shine?! Jack struggles not to look back at the source of the jeer. He settles in at the plate. JOHNNY SAIN on the mound waiting for the sign. The crowd BUZZING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sain looking in. When he's got that fastball working, he can toss a lamb chop past a hungry wolf. The BRAVES CATCHER signals a 1'. Here come the pitch. CRACK! It's down the third base line. The THIRD BASEMAN is going to need every ounce of his arm as he fields it at the line, throw across his body to -- FIRST. Where Jack's foot hits the bag an instant before the ball smacks into the first baseman's mitt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're out! Jack can't believe it. As he trots toward the dugout he looks at the umpire who looks back: I dare you to complain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the Brooklyn faithful BOO the call, Rachel and Smith watch Jack head decisively toward the dugout. He was safe. Rickey sits down closer to the dugout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a game of inches, Jackie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get some glasses, ump!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - DODGER OFFICES - DAY 118A BURT SHOTTON, 62, walks down the hallway with Parrott. INSERT: April 18, 1947. PARROTT How's Florida, Burt? SHOTTON Roses need pruning, but fine when I left it last night. Branch said it was important and I heard about Leo. Any idea what this is about? PARROTT You'd better just talk to him. A beat as they reach the door. Parrott knocks. RICKEY'S VOICE Come in! 118B INT. BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 118B Rickey smiles from his desk as they enter. TAN REV 6-25-12 73.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baseball has returned to Brooklyn, Burt. Another season is underway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's a shame about Leo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inevitable I suppose. I asked him if she was worth it and he said yes. How's the retirement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fine. The roses -- RICKEY It's a helluva thing when a man has good health and enough money and absolutely nothing to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm perfectly happy. RICKEY Is that so? SHOTTON When I took off that Cleveland uniform two years ago, I promised the Mrs. I'd never put on another uniform again. Roses look great and I sleep a whole lot better. RICKEY Roses and sleep are two wonderful things, Burt. But sleep you can get inside your casket and flowers look good on top of it. You don't look like a dead man to me. SHOTTON What's this about, Branch? TAN REV 6-25-12 73A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need you to manage the Dodgers. We're a ship without a captain; there's a typhoon ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm sorry, but no. RICKEY Do you miss the game, Burt? Look me in the eye and tell me you don't. Shotton considers Rickey a beat and then looks away. SHOTTON Baseball's the only life for an old pepper pot like me, but I promised my wife, Branch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You promised her you wouldn't put on another uniform. You didn't promise her you wouldn't manage. Wear a suit and tie; Connie Mack still does. (A BEAT) You remember how to get to the Polo Grounds, Burt? SHOTTON Branch, I -- RICKEY You remember what the peanuts smell like roasting, how the crack of the bat sounds, the roar of the crowd? SHOTTON Sure... Rickey tosses him a set of car keys. RICKEY My car's parked right out front. Harold will show you where. Now what do you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VISITOR'S LOCKER ROOM - POLO GROUNDS - HARLEM - DAY 119 Shotton addresses the half-dressed Dodgers, Jack included.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men, I don't have much to say. Just, don't be afraid of old Burt Shotton as a manager. You can win the pennant in spite of me. I can not possibly hurt you. The Dodgers trade looks. Not exactly inspirational. As Shotton heads out he pauses by Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you Robinson? (JACK NODS) I thought so. Shotton pats Jack on the shoulder, continues on his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRESS BOX - THE POLO GROUNDS - DAY 120 A huge CROWD beyond. Bob Cooke of the Herald Tribune (seen at the Waldorf Astoria) holds court as Jack is ANNOUNCED.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark my words and circle this date. Negroes are going to run the white man straight out of baseball. I'm not prejudiced; it's physiological. They have a longer heel bone. Gives em an unfair speed advantage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - POLO GROUNDS 121 Standing dead still at the plate, bat cocked and ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's Robinson. Jackie holds that club down by the end. Rear foot on the back line of the box. Slight open stance, bent at the knees... Giants pitcher DAVE KOSLO goes into his wind-up and throws. Jack swings. CRACK. The ball screams out to left. Home run! The crowd goes crazy. This is what they came to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Typewriters pounding away as Jack finishes his home run trot. Bob Cooke watching thoughtfully as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was that because his heels are longer, Bob?! As everyone cracks up, everyone but Bob...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAWSON BOWMAN'S CAFA - HARLEM - NIGHT 123 Jack and Rachel out for dinner. Jack nodding as BLACK PATRONS pass by, saying encouraging things. He almost gets a forkful of food to his mouth before a MENU and a PEN are offered for an autograph. As he signs, a FLASH BULB goes off. In a lull, Jack cuts his steak, low to Rachel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not complaining, I just, I don't know what they want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They want to see if Jackie Robinson is real. They want to see your pride, your dignity. Because then they'll see it in themselves. He's stopped short. She blinks with mock coquettish modesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And me? I'm just young and scared and amazed at how brave you are. He grins at her, almost gets a forkful in when LAWSON BOWMAN, the Black owner, pulls up a chair, shakes Jack's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Lawson Bowman, Jack, the owner of this joint. How's the steak?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure yet. It looks good.
direction.name: direction

Back on his feet, he spits out a piece of grit he picked up sliding back on his belly. Not bothering to dust himself off, he's turning into something elemental before our eyes.

direction.raw_text: . EBBETS FIELD STANDS (BETWEEN FIRST AND HOME) - DAY 152C The Brooklyn fans cheer; the Racist fan sulks. The double is little comfort to Rachel who stares ahead, sitting as straight up as she can. Willing herself not to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROOKLYN CITY BUS - DAY 154 Jack and Rachel ride home. Forlorn, she stares out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jack...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Rae?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. It's just, sometimes when I sit up there with those bastards, those loudmouths in the stands, I know you can hear them. JACK Don't worry. It's okay. RACHEL No, it's not okay. And I can hear them, too. Jack looks at her, takes her hand in his. JACK I know. I'm sorry for that. Rachel squeezes his hand back. RACHEL We're in it together. When they start in on you, you know what I do? I try to sit up as straight. JACK Yeah? RACHEL Straight as I can. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it in my head that I can block it from you, some of it, if I sit up straight. (a sad smile) Isn't that dumb? Closing the space between them, he takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It worked. I didn't hear a thing. She tries to smiles. As the tears streak her cheeks, he leans in kisses her forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're just ignorant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they knew you, they'd be ashamed. She puts her arm around him, draws that strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am holding on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long as we hold on, it'll be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STANDS - EBBETS FIELD - DAY 155 WHACK! Rachel and Rickey watch Jack taking batting practice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look lovely, Mrs. Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how you do it. Every day, from the 1st to the 9th. Myself? I could pay $100 for a suit and in twenty minutes I'd look like I fell out of bed. Even my shoes look rumpled. They watch Jack crack one high off the Schaefer Beer sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to think Jack was conceited. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 93.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was the very first thing I noticed about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you two meet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw him at a UCLA football game. Even in uniform with a helmet on, his vanity was awful. It was the way he held his hands on his hips. I hated him! (RICKEY LAUGHS) And on campus he always wore crisp white shirts and I'd think his skin is so dark, why would he do that? Then I got to know him, his pride and confidence, and I realized he was showing off his color. I was wrong. He wasn't conceited; he was proud. Always, of who and what he is. I'd never met another man like that. What about you? How did you meet your wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trying to catch her in a race. She was the fastest girl in town. Beautiful legs. I finally caught up; we've been together ever since. They sit a moment. Below: Jack nails another one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to apologize to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything. I can't apologize to him. He and I both knew what we were getting into. But you. A newlywed, trying to blossom a marriage under all this pressure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about me. Or us. We know who we are. Crack. Jack hits another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your husband has humbled me. When this all began I thought I was changing the world and that Jackie was my instrument. Can you imagine? I wish I could help him, but I'm just a spectator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You help him plenty. Believe me. They watch him rip into another pitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he able to get things off his chest? So he doesn't burn up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I have to let him have that silence at first, let him come to me. But he opens up eventually.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. It's too much to carry inside. Does he have any friends on the team? (she gives him a look) They're spectators, too. They do admire him though. Rachel looks out to where Reese and Stanky play catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even the worst of us recognizes courage. Moral courage especially. I have to think they see it. Jackie's a man on trial. He's responding with glory and grace. No one can take their eyes off him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's had himself on trial since the day I met him. No man is harder on himself or gets to himself worse than Jack. But I hope his team- mates know, they're on trial too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose we all are. You're an astute woman, Mrs. Robinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to be, Mr. Rickey, I'm married to a man of destiny. I can't let him down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'd met you first, I wouldn't have looked so long for Jackie. RACHEL How do you mean? RICKEY I mean if he was good enough for you, he's certainly good enough for the rest of us. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PENNOCK'S OFFICE - SHIBE PARK - DAY 156 Phillie GM HERB PENNOCK at his desk, on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch, it's Herb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 157 RICKEY What can I do for you, Herb?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have we known each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty years. Maybe more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then trust me when I say, Brooklyn's due here tomorrow, but you can not bring that Nigger down here with the rest of your team. Rickey grits his teeth, stays civil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And why's that, Herb? His name's Jackie Robinson by the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're just not ready for this sort of thing in Philadelphia. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 95aA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure we'll be able to take the field against your team if that boy is in uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Herbert, what your team does is your decision. But my team is coming to Philadelphia. With Robinson. If we have to claim the game as a forfeit, we will. That's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in case you forgot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Branch, you've got one helluva hair across your ass on this thing and I, for one, would like to know what you're trying to prove? RICKEY Do you think God likes baseball? I do. PENNOCK What the hell does that mean? RICKEY It means you're going to meet God one day, Herb, and when he inquires why Robinson wasn't on the field in Philadelphia and you answer because he was a Negro, it may not be a sufficient reply. As Rickey hangs up the phone... CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BENJAMIN FRANKLIN HOTEL - DAY 159 The Dodger TEAM BUS pulls up. The doors whoosh open; Parrott steps off looking official. As the players start to follow: INSERT: May 9, 1947. Benjamin Franklin Hotel, Philadelphia. PARROTT Come on, fellas! We have twenty minutes to check in and then get to Shibe! Chop chop. No one is listening as the TEAM DRIVER opens the lower compartment and the players (including Jack) grab their bags. HOTEL MANAGER Out! Get that bus out of here! The HOTEL MANAGER stalks over, flanked by HOTEL SECURITY. PARROTT We're the Dodgers. We have a reservation. HOTEL MANAGER Your team's not welcome, not while you have ballclub Negroes with you. PARROTT You mean Robinson can't stay here? HOTEL MANAGER I mean the entire team is refused! PARROTT We've been staying here ten years. HOTEL MANAGER And you can stay away that long! SHOTTEN (last off the bus) Hold on now, let's talk about this. The Hotel Manager jerks his thumb like an umpire. HOTEL MANAGER Get out! Now, grandpa! SHOTTEN Grandpa? Hey hold on, you! Security getting between as Shotten and the Manager go at it. BLUE REV 4-07-12 96A. Jack is embarrassed, but what can he do? Walker says to no one in particular, but loud enough for Jack to hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe 42's got enough friends in town, we can bunk up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that supposed to mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. It's just, I know when you can't get into a hotel, you got people's houses you can stay at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want from me, Walker?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An apology. JACK (STEPS FORWARD) For what? Places like this? Parrott alarmed at this turn of events. WALKER For turning this season into a sideshow! I'm a ballplayer; I want to play ball! JACK So am I! I'm here to win! WALKER How the hell are we gonna win sleeping on the bus?! PARROTT FELLAS -- JACK It might do you some good the way you're swinging the bat lately. DIXIE Watch your mouth! PINK REV 4-19-12 97. Walker jabs his chest with a finger; Jack bats his hand away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch your damn hand! And they're lunging at each other. Separated by Reese, Stanky, Branca and Bragan while other players hold off Shotton. Two fights about to break out at the same time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa?! I'll show you grandpa! Parrott summons something deep, lets loose a shrill WHISTLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fellas! Burt! Please! Take the bus to the field! Worry about the game. I'll find another hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PENNOCK'S OFFICE - SHIBE PARK - DAY 160 Ben Chapman sits across from Herb Pennock who flips through underlined newspaper reports. Pennock reads one:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a great lynch mob among us; they go unhooded and work without rope. (looks at him) That's you, not me. (reads some more) We must remember that all this country's enemies are not beyond the frontiers of our home land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some Jew must've wrote that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This doesn't look good, Ben! It makes the Phillies, look racist! You've got to do something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VISITOR'S LOCKER ROOM - SHIBE PARK - NIGHT 161 ON PARROTT. He's trying to work up the nerve for something. Finally, he comes around the corner where Jack sits at his locker talking to Smith. PARROTT Jackie, excuse me, um, a request came in. The Phillies manager Ben Chapman, he'd like his photo taken with you. Jack pretends to sniff the air around Parrott.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You been drinking, Harold?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rickey thinks it's a good idea. He says it'll be in every sports page in the country. An example that'll show everyone even the most hardened man can change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chapman hasn't changed. He's just trying to take the heat off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rickey says it doesn't matter if he's changed. As long as it looks like he's changed. Chapman said he'd come down here. Or meet you in the runway. As Jack slow burns...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See the ball come in slow. See the photo come in slower. JACK (TO PARROTT) Tell him on the field. Where everyone can see him. As Parrott smiles; he's done it. PARROT Perfect. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOME PLATE - SHIBE PARK - NIGHT 162 Chapman and Jack stand side-by-side facing the PRESS. Chapman makes a little speech. Hypocrisy at its best.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie's been accepted in baseball and the Philadelphia organization wish him all the luck we can. I only hope in some small way our trial of fire... helped him along. Jack looks at him: Did he just say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about a picture? Shake hands. Bury the hatchet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a picture? Sure. Jack steps to the on-deck circle, grabs a BASEBALL BAT. Chapman's eyes widen as he starts toward him with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (low to Chapman) We'll hold the bat. That way we don't have to touch skin. Chapman nods, looks relieved. A photographer hands over a bat. Chapman has two hands on the handle. Jack puts one hand on the barrel, the other stays on his hip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, I hope all your friends back home like the picture. Jack smiles as the flashbulbs go off. Chapman looks dumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the dugout with Stanky, watches in disbelief. WALKER Carl, I swear, I never thought I'd see ol' Ben eat shit like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORBES FIELD - PITTSBURGH - DAY 163 FRITZ OSTERMUELLER on the mound. He takes a long look in at Jack, at his catcher KLUTTZ who flicks his thumb: a Hit him.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : May 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Here it comes. All Jack has time to do is cover his face to lessen the blow. Beaned in the head, he goes down in a heap. Branca leads the Dodger players out onto the field. The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: move to head them off. Pirates as well. Kirby Higbe, now in a Pirate uniform, claps his hands pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in his face) Ostermeuller, you kraut! You gotta bat, too! Don't you forget!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ready, you Wop bastard!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's gonna come right between your eyes! Like a Kamikaze! OSTERMUELLER (RE: JACK) For him!? He doesn't belong here! BRANCA You don't belong here! Go home to Goering and Shmelling! OSTERMUELLER Make me, you goddamn dago! WHITE 3-14-12 100. As an UMPIRE gets between them, Jack sits up. He's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 164 Rickey looks up as Reese enters. He holds a LETTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What can I do for you, Pee Wee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Mr. Rickey, it's like this, the series in Cincinnati next week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an important road trip, we're only three games out of first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. You know, I'm from Kentucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cincinnati's nearly a home game for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got this letter, sir. I guess some people aren't too happy about me playing with Robinson. Rickey is not liking where this is going; he motions for the letter, scans it, reads the highlights...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nigger lover. Watch yourself. We will get you, carpetbagger. (holds it out) Typical stuff. Reese takes the letter back, a little hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not typical to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many of these letters have you gotten, Pee Wee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just this. Ain't that enough? Rickey looks Reese over a moment. Pushing back his chair he steps over to a filing cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Motioning Reese to join him, he pulls open a drawer, pulls out a 4-inch stack of flattened letters, then another, then a third. He looks to Reese.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are those?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you what they aren't, they aren't letters from the Jackie Robinson fan club. Here -- He thrusts a sheaf of it into Reese's hands. As Reese flips through the stack of hate, reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of baseball, or your baby boy will die. (NEXT ONE) Quit baseball or your Nigger wife will be... Reese trails off, won't say it out loud. Skips to another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of the game or be killed. He looks at one more, reacts to the vitriol, but does not utter it. Reese looks back at Rickey, shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does Jackie know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course he knows. And the FBI. They're taking a threat in Cincinnati pretty seriously. So excuse me if I'm not too shocked at you being called a carpetbagger. You should be proud of it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd just like to play ball, Mr. Rickey. That's all we want to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. I bet Jackie just wants to play ball. I bet he wishes he wasn't leading the league in hit by pitch. I bet he wishes people didn't want to kill him. But the world isn't so simple anymore. I'm not sure it ever was. We just, baseball ignored it. Now we can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Sir. I gotta get to practice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the stands. Freckled, cute. Looking at the men around him, his own FATHER SHOUTING at Jack as the Dodgers take the field (the Reds coming off it). Jack headed for first. Pee Wee out to short. FRECKLES Nigger! (then...) We don't want you here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Crosley Field, Cincinnati, June 21, 1947.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cincinnati fans expressing their displeasure as the Dodgers take the field. Jackie Robinson at first. The Brat Eddie Stanky at second. Spider Jorgensen at third. And the captain Pee Wee Reese at shortstop. (A BEAT) Ask any man and they'll tell you that the Gillette Superspeed razor is a honey. Maybe the sweetest shaving razor you'll ever use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INFIELD - CROSLEY FIELD - DAY 168 Jack reaches first, throws the ball around the infield. Many in the crowd beyond rise to jeer and heap abuse. COON!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Jack tries to let it wash over him. At short, Reese receives the ball, moves to throw to first when he pauses. Deciding, he suddenly moves to trot across the diamond until he's alongside Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up? Now cries of CARPETBAGGER! cut through. PEE WEE, HOW CAN YOU PLAY WITH THIS BLACK BASTARD!? Reese stares up at the worst hecklers along the first base line. He looks a little sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can say what they want; we're here to play baseball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a bunch of crackpots still fighting the Civil War.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, we'd a won that son of a gun if the cornstalks had held out. We just ran out of ammunition. Jack laughs. Reese has a funny way of saying it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better luck next time, Pee Wee. Reese impulsively puts his arm around Jack's shoulder, stares into the Cincy dugout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ain't gonna be a next time. All we got is right now. This right here. Know what I mean? Walker reacting out in right. The crowd shuts down, some in shock at the gesture. Jack surprised also.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PEE WEE, HOW CAN YOU PLAY WITH THIS BLACK BASTARD

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Jackie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you thanking me for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got family here from Louisville. Up there somewhere. I need a em to know who I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jack moved by Pee Wee's gesture, can't find the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robinson and Reese conferring at first. Maybe discussing an infield shift on Baumholtz. UMPIRE Hey! Number one! You playing ball or socializing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Playing ball, ump! Playing ball! (TO JACK) Maybe tomorrow we'll all wear 42. That way they won't be able to tell us apart. Reese heads for short. Jack pounds his fist in his glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN - ENROUTE TO NEW YORK - DAY 171 Jack playing Gin Rummy with Branca, Reese and Wendell Smith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Smith; teasing) You ever write about white guys in your paper? I mean, if I threw a no hitter and Jackie got a base hit, what would the headline be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie leads Dodgers to victory. Again. Under that: white Italian guy does ok. They all laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd call your folks for ya, Ralph. Tell a em how you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No problem. It'll still make the Post. They play their hands as they talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are on some kind of winning streak, huh boys? And I don't mean cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, maybe forty of our last fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty-two and fifteen actually. Since the 4th of July.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Math is why I throw a baseball for a living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This next series against the Cardinals, it's a big one. They look over at Jack who hasn't said a word. It's his play. He lays his cards down. Deadpan as he wins the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gin.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: B172 DIXIE WALKER AT BAT B172

direction.raw_text: The top of the 11th inning, all tied at 2. For those of you just tuning in, how did we get here? CUT TO: A172 JACK AT BAT A172 Jack strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky breaks off second for third. RED BARBER'S VOICE It's been double trouble as Robinson knocked in Stanky with a double in the third... B172 DIXIE WALKER AT BAT B172 Walker strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky breaks off second for third. RED BARBER'S VOICE ...And Dixie Walker did the same with a double in the eighth. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 105A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EBBETS FIELD - DAY 172 ENOS SLAUGHTER steps in for St. Louis. Hugh Casey on the mound for Brooklyn. Slaughter looks fiercely determined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't enough as the Cardinals tied it with two of their own in the top of the ninth. This game is crucial to the Red Birds. They're five games out, the Dodgers having not relinquished first place sine June 30th. Casey throws a pitch. Inside, a ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : August 20, 1947. Brooklyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slaughter takes ball one low. Casey in his second inning of relief. This game is tighter than a new pair of shoes on a rainy day. Slaughter hitless in four trips as Casey goes into his wind-up. Slaughter swings, hits a hard ground ball right at Reese who fires over to Jack at first. Slaughter is out by fifteen feet, but he never slows down. And his foot comes down -- -- High on Jack's right calf. Slaughter's spiked him something wicked. Jack goes down in a heap clutching his leg, blood already seeping through his high socks. Slaughter, head down, on his way to the visitor's dugout as Dodger players pour out of their own to protest. As the UMP raises his hands, motions them all back... Jack pulls up his sock, a bloody mess. Stanky looks to Casey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next batter, throw right at his head. Clean his clock -- JACK (FIERCE) Just get him out. Understand? Game's too important. As Casey nods, Jack reaches up to Stanky and Reese. They pull him to his feet. Jack looks, finds Rachel in the stands. As he gives her a little wave: a I'm okay.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big Cardinal slugger at bat. Casey pitching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The top of the 12th and Kurowski at the plate. He hit his 20th home run on Monday so Casey's going to want to be careful with him. The pitch grooves in and Kurowski nails it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh dear. There goes number 21.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EBBETS FIELD 174 The Cardinals leading 3-2 going into the bottom of the 12th.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stadium electric as Jack steps in, his left leg bloody. He takes an inside pitch at the knees. Bastards! Here comes the next one. WHACK - He singles hard up the middle, nearly takes the pitcher's head off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rounds hard, returns to the bag. Reiser stepping up to the plate as Musial holds Jack on at first. Jack in a fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care what happens, I don't care what kind of play it is, when I get to second I'm gonna knock someone into centerfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (glances at blood) I don't blame you, man, you got every right. Jack running on the pitch. Reiser bunts. The play is to first. Reiser is out and Jack slides safe into second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has the sense to vacate before he gets there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bouncing up and down, wearing that badge of potential violence and action. The crowd buzzing, the electricity practically hits you in the face. Jack's going to score.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming up out of his seat along with the fans around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker at bat. Jack steps out, checks on MARION the shortstop. He takes another step out, looks to Schoendienst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (over it all) Munger sets. Robbie back and forth off second. The third bag clearly in his sights. Oh, and Munger deals a pick off throw to Marion at second and Robinson is out! Marion breaks for the bag and Munger turns and fires a strike. Marion brings down the tag -- Out! He is and he knows it. The crowd stunned into silence. Jack frozen a moment, head down, furious with himself. Low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cardinals pick up a game. It was one of those plays where you do or you don't and Jackie didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAINER'S TABLE - DODGER CLUBHOUSE - DAY 176 Jack on his stomach as STITCHES are sewn into his leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he spike you on purpose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You saw the play. I had my foot inside the bag. He was out by a mile. But he kept coming. REPORTER TWO Slaughter said it was an accident. JACK What are you asking me for then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you calling Slaughter a liar?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . This guy's a real jerk. Rickey arrives, a BASEBALL in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out. Let me talk to my first baseman. Go. He's getting stitched up for Pete's sake. The reporters move off for other interviews. Reporter Two hesitant to let it go, finally drifts off. Rickey watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sticking up for yourself is what you'd expect of any man. Some find it galling to see it in a Negro.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Mr. Rickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry? Sorry for what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lost my cool out there. It probably cost us the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, Jackie, all the best base runners get caught sometimes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't thinking. Rickey pulls up a chair sits across from him, leans in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what I saw this morning? I was passing a sandlot and a little white boy was up to bat. You know what he was doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sitting on a fastball?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was pretending he was you. Wiping his hands on his pants, swinging with his arms outstretched like you do. A little white boy pretending he was a black man. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAINER'S TABLE - DODGER CLUBHOUSE - DAY 178 The two men, who have done so much, looking each other over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had victory over fascism in Germany; it's time for victory over racism at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you doing this? Come on now. A long moment between them. Finally, Rickey looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love this game. I love baseball. I've given my life to it. Forty odd years ago I was a player coach at Ohio Wesleyan University. We had a Negro catcher, best hitter on the team. Charley Thomas. Rickey starts slowly rubbing the baseball in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fine young man. I saw him laid low. Broken because of the color of his skin and I didn't do enough to help. I told myself I did, but I didn't. The game I loved had something unfair at the heart of it. I ignored it. But a time came when I could no longer do that. (LOOKS UP) You let me love baseball again. Thank you. Jack's eyes gentle on Rickey's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rickey fighting back tears now, retreats to his more confident self. RICKEY You're a force of nature, Jackie, you've complicated everything but yourself. You're changing the world, and refusing to let it change you. I for one am in awe. Jack reaches, takes the baseball from him. A beat as they consider each other. Finally, a promise... JACK I won't get picked off second base again. Not this year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - 526 MACDONOUGH STREET - BROOKLYN - DAY 184 It's early. Rachel watches from bed as Jack finishes packing. She looks sad. Jack looks into the cradle at Jackie Jr..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's pop's last long road trip of the year, little man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful you don't wake him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. I won't. (LOOKS OVER) You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like seeing you leave, that's all. He looks at her a beat, resumes packing... JACK I'll be home in a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleven days. That's a long time without you. He doesn't answer, packs away. Finally: RACHEL Try not to lunge at the plate. JACK Seriously?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why they're throwing the fastballs inside. He looks at her, a little shocked.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: 179 OMITTED 179 180 OMITTED 180 181 OMITTED 181 182 OMITTED 182 GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 111

direction.raw_text: Fight those inside fastballs off, foul them back. Sooner or later they won't be able to help but throw a curve. He steps to the bed, leans over her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what'll happen then? She clucks a 'hit' sound, makes an 'ahhhhhh' crowd sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We win enough of these next games and we'll bring home the pennant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pennant? Where are we going to put a pennant? All these baby diapers hanging everywhere. Jack looks around the room, at the diapers hanging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got room right over there. Between number one and number two. She mock grimaces at his bad joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Win one if you have to, but bring yourself home; that'll be plenty. They kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rae, you're in my heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Promise me you'll come home. That you'll always come home. As he looks at all he loves in the world...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MACDONOUGH STREET - BROOKLYN - DAY 184A Jack exits MacDonough Street apartment building and makes his way down the street. 185 OMITTED 185 BUFF REV 5-29-12 113-114.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SPORTSMAN PARK - ST. LOUIS - DAY 188A A CARDINAL RUNNER on second. Jackie holding another RUNNER on first as the St. Louis crowd ROARS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 2 on 2 out for the Cardinals in the eighth. Anxious moments now as they've cut the Dodger lead to 2. Nippy Jones up. Musial taking his place on deck. Jones likes to punch that ball when he swings. Insert: September 13, 1947. Casey on the mound receives the ball. Pounds his glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Casey, get him out! Pitch that ball!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: -- 189 OMITTED 189 190 OMITTED 190 191 OMITTED 191 192 OMITTED 192 BUFF REV 5-29-12 115

direction.raw_text: The outfield is deep, shaded toward left. Robinson holding the runner on first. Here comes Casey with the pitch -- Jones swings, pops it up. BARBER It's popped up foul toward first. Should be out of play. But here comes Robinson, he's coming hard -- 189 OMITTED 189 190 OMITTED 190 191 OMITTED 191 192 OMITTED 192 BUFF REV 5-29-12 115.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 193 EXT. SPORTSMAN PARK - ST. LOUIS - DAY 193 Jack chasing down the foul, headed right for the open steps of his own dugout. He never considers the peril as he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and his left foot comes down onto nothing -- BRANCA LEAPS forward, tackles Jack back onto the infield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got it! And one of the Dodgers has him! CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VISITOR'S LOCKER ROOM - SPORTSMAN PARK - DAY 196 BARBER'S VOICE The Dodgers closing in on the Pennant as they'll leave St. Louis for Cincinnati and a three game series with the Reds. Jack sits in his grass stained pants after the game. Most of the guys are in the shower. Branca, a towel around his waist, is headed there himself. The sight of Jack stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I ask you something, Jackie? How come you never shower until everyone else is done? Jack just stares at him. Branca won't let it drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shy or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to make anyone uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're a team. On a hot streak. Half the wins on account of you. You're the bravest guy I ever saw. You're leading us and you're afraid to take a shower? A beat as Jack considers him. Stone-faced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. Take a shower with me. (A BEAT) Hey, I don't mean it like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Dodgers showering, guys chattering. Suddenly, there's Branca and Jack at the shower entrance. All eyes look over. Branca enters. Then Jack. A beat and everyone goes back to getting clean. It's no big deal. Except... Dixie Walker looks to the floor, shakes his head. Finally, quietly, he leaves. Who's the loneliest man on the team now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE - BROOKLYN - DAY 198 As the phone rings, Rickey grabs it. On edge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : September 16, 1947 RICKEY Rickey here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a payphone in the CROSLEY FIELD CONCOURSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We did it, Boss! We did it! We swept Cincinnati! That puts us seven games up. Joyous, Rickey grabs a sheet showing the NL standings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And eliminates the Giants and Boston. He puts an a X' through Boston and the Giants. The rest of the NL are already crossed out. Only the Cardinals remain. At the same time, Parrott X's the same out on his notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd have to lose nearly every game for the Cardinals to catch us now. One more win may do it. Who's pitching tomorrow for the Pirates?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ostermueller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MACDONOUGH STREET - BROOKLYN - DAY 199A Rachel walks pushing Jackie Junior in his stroller. As she moves, the RADIO BROADCAST of the Dodgers' game can be heard from one house to the next. In a gap, a passing car picks it up and we hear it from the window. Then another house. BARBER'S VOICE A very big game today here in Pittsburgh. A win and the Dodgers will have clinched the National League Pennant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EBBETS FIELD - DAY 199B Branch Rickey alone in the stadium. The field empty as he listens to the call of the game over the PA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fritz Ostermueller on the mound. He's 12 and 8 on the season.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORBES FIELD - PITTSBURGH - DAY 200 INSERT: September 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Ostermueller on the rubber. Staring in at Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't belong! You'll never belong! Jack waits. Ostermueller pitches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes the pitch and Robinson takes outside. Ball one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ON MACDONOUGH STREET 200A Listening as -- DBL. WHITE REV 6-28-12 117A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ostermueller winds and throws, low and away ball two. Fritz seems to be pitching around Jackie. Or trying to get him to chase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Throw him a strike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORBES FIELD - PITTSBURGH - DAY 200B Shakes off one sign, then nods at the next. Throws the ball well outside. Another pitch outside. aBall Three!a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 3 and 0 now. Robinson waiting on something he can swing on. As catcher Kluttz throws it back...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me something I can hit! (TO HIMSELF) What are you afraid of?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want it?! (TO HIMSELF) Careful what you wish for boy... Ostermueller nods at the sign. Jack about to slay the dragon as the pitch comes in - WHACK! The ball is going for a ride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is a deep fly ball to left. Kiner on his horse, but I don't think he'll get there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rickey standing, looking up like he can see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back, back, back and oh doctor! Robinson got his pitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ball sails out: HOME RUN! Ostermueller hangs his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITE REV 6-28-12 117B.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MACDONOUGH STREET APARTMENT - BROOKLYN - DAY 200E Rachel listening, smiling as CHEERS sound from outside the apartment. We hear the sound of car horns on the street. 200F JACK 200F He runs toward first and we run with him. The smile starts somewhere in his body. His heart most likely. By the time it reaches his face, his joy has erupted. The weight of the world starting to drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kirby Higbe who watches Robinson round the bases in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pittsburgh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nears second on his home run trot. Even the Pittsburgh crowd starting to applaud him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rickey absorbing the moment. It's almost too much. 204 JACKIE ROBINSON 204 Rounding second and headed for third. The weight of the world somehow lifting. They gave him one he could hit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're tight on Jack's back as he heads for home at Forbes Field. 90 feet away... 75...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally inspired to type: T-h-a-n-k y-o-u, J-a-c-k-i-e.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nearing home. About to step on the plate. He closes his eyes as well and -- WE CUT TO:
